author: Andries Mahlangu
title: JSE perks up in line with global trends | Markets
text:
Picture: MICHAEL ETTERSHANK THE JSE pushed higher on Wednesday in line with the improving sentiment on global equity markets after a recent sell-off.
The all share index was up 1.28% to 50,017.30 points in early afternoon trade, with the blue chip top 40 recovering 1.51%.
Investors largely picked up the recently beaten down shares from the industrial and financial sectors at the tail end of a volatile and weak quarter for global markets.
"This quarter has probably been one of the worst performing ones for global equities markets in six years," MyWealth Investments CE Devin Shutte said.
"The combination of the Greek crisis, the Chinese currency devaluation, low commodity prices and uncertainty over the US Fed (Federal Reserve) interest rates have all added to negative investor sentiment, and very little risk appetite for equities."
The damage in third quarter was mostly concentrated in the resources complex, where the resources 10 index has shed a hefty 19%. Financial shares slid 4% while industrials bucked the weaker trend, thanks to a big rally by SABMiller.
Europe’s leading share markets were higher at midday, after a roundly positive session in Asia where Japan’s Nikkei 225 picked up 2.7%.
Among some individual shares on the JSE, troubled global miner Glencore regained 12% to R18.71 after announcing it is addressing its $30bn debt problem.
Petrochemical giant Sasol was up 2.69% to R387.96 while Kumba Iron Ore rose 4.29% to R79.21.
Market focus was on SABMiller ahead of the expected takeover bid from AB InBev. SABMiller was 3.09% higher at R783.47.
Platinum producer Lonmin recovered 9.62% to R3.42% as platinum prices recovered slightly from multi-year lows.
Capitec added 1.14% to R494.84 after delivering strong interim results earlier in the week.
Old Mutual was up 2.71% to R39.75 and Liberty Holdings gained 2.84% to R125.20.
